nodes.text: Using support vector machines (SVM) at the segment/classification level and integrating SVM with HMM will improve handwritten numeral recognition accuracy compared to neural network/HMM or HMM alone
SVMs offer better discrimination and generalization (large margin, structural risk minimization) than neural networks for classification tasks
Replacing the neural network classifier in a hybrid NN/HMM system with an SVM at the segment classification level is feasible and expected to improve hybrid recognizer performance
Feature extraction used for SVM input comprises 18 features: seven moment invariants, seven thinned-moment invariants, and four affine moment invariant features
Experiments use optical recognition datasets including UCI Optdigits (8x8 preprocessed) and a collected Assamese character dataset (8235 samples from 45 writers)
SVM training used radial basis function kernel with grid search for C and gamma; final chosen parameters included C = 8 and a selected gamma value
In testing the implemented system the classifier correctly identified 98% of the testing data in the reported analysis
Across the three isolated-character databases tested, SVM recognition rates were higher than Hidden Markov Model recognition rates
SVM models typically require substantially more storage because memory scales with number of support vectors times number of features (here 350 features)
Storage can be reduced by compactly storing original online signals with pen-up/pen-down status and dynamically expanding the SVM model during recognition

Integrating the SVM character recognizer into an HMM-based word recognizer is expected to improve word recognition rates because character-level discrimination from SVM will raise word likelihood estimates
Reducing the number of support vectors requires finer hyperparameter grid search and reduced-set selection methods and is an identified area for further work
Multiclass numeral recognition was handled by applying binary SVMs in a one-versus-rest scheme
